images.description: My group of friends had a weekly "movie night" during winters on Martha's Vineyard, and we'd take turns making a chocolate treat to share. These terrific cookies were an instant success. Once they debuted, I had to make them many more times. —Laura Bryant German, W. Warren, Massachusetts Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Peppermint Biscotti
images.description: Dipped in melted chocolate and rolled in crushed peppermint candy, this flavorful biscotti is a favorite. It's one of the many sweets I make for Christmas. —Paula Marchesi, Lenhartsville, Pennsylvania Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Italian Rainbow Cookies
images.description: My family has made these classic Italian cookies for generations, and this homemade version is so much better than the bakery version. They are always a special treat during the holidays or any time of year!—Cindy Casazza, Hopewell, New Jersey Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Peanut Butter Christmas Mice
images.description: With their red licorice tails, candy noses and peanut ears, these chewy "mice" were always a hit at classroom parties. My children are in their teens now, but they still ask me to make these cookies for the holidays. -Nancy Rowse Bella Vista, Arkansas Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Christmas Sandwich Cremes
images.description: These melt-in-your-mouth sandwich cookies have a scrumptious filling. I helped my sister make these in high school when she needed a project in her home economics class. She got an A+! —Janice Poechman, Walkerton, Ontario Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Buttery Spritz Cookies
images.description: These tender little cookies are very eye-catching on my Christmas cookie tray. The dough is easy to work with, so it's fun to make these into a variety of festive shapes. —Beverly Launius, Sandwich, Illinois Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Pizzelle
images.description: This recipe was adapted from one used by my Italian-born mother and grandmother. They used old irons on a gas stove, but now we have the convenience of electric pizzelle irons. The cookies are so delectable and beautiful, they're worth it! —Elizabeth Schwartz, Trevorton, Pennsylvania Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Coconut Clouds
images.description: Coconut lovers will have extra reason to celebrate when they taste these cake-like drop cookies. The generous frosting and coconut topping make them a hit at holiday cookie swaps. —Donna Scofield, Yakima, Washington Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Snickerdoodles
images.description: The history of this whimsically named treat is widely disputed, but the popularity of this classic cinnamon-sugar-coated cookie is undeniable! —Taste of Home Test Kitchen Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Peppermint Meltaways
images.description: This recipe is very pretty and festive-looking on a cookie platter. I often cover a plate of these meltaways with red or green plastic wrap and a bright holiday bow in one corner. And yes, they really do melt in your mouth! —Denise Wheeler, Newaygo, Michigan Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Frosted Eggnog Cookies
images.description: Eggnog stars in both the cookie and frosting in this new-found recipe, imparting a subtle holiday flavor.—Amanda Taylor, Glen Ewen, Saskatchewan Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Gingerbread Oatmeal Cookies
images.description: Cookie butter and ground ginger add a new layer of flavor. The recipe makes about 2 dozen cookies; they go fast so you may want to make a double batch. —Carole Resnick, Cleveland, Ohio Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Jeweled Coconut Drops
images.description: Red raspberry preserves add a festive flair to these tender coconut cookies. Perfect for potlucks and cookie exchanges, these shaped cookies never last long when I make them for my husband and two sons. -Ellen Marie Byler Munfordville, Kentucky Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Dipped Gingersnaps
images.description: I get a great deal of satisfaction making and giving time-tested yuletide treats like these soft, chewy cookies. Dipping them in white chocolate makes great gingersnaps even more special. —Laura Kimball, West Jordan, Utah Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Pistachio-Cranberry Rugelach
images.description: Traditional rugelach gets dressed up for the holiday with pistachios, cranberries, and snow-white icing. Rich but not too sweet! — Deborah Hinojosa, Saratoga, California Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Chocolate-Covered Cherry Cookies
images.description: I always make these cookies for family gatherings, and they never last very long. They require a little extra effort, but they're worth it. —Marie Kinyon, Mason, Michigan Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Scottish Shortbread
images.description: Scottish settlers first came to this area over 150 years ago. My mother herself was Scottish, and—as with most of my favorite recipes—she passed this on to me. I make a triple batch of it each year at Christmas, to enjoy and as gifts. —Rose Mabee, Selkirk, Manitoba Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Holiday Almond Tassies
images.description: I make so many of these fancy tassies every year, I use up a 7-pound container of almond paste! They’re one of my family’s holiday favorites. —Donna Westhouse, Dorr, Michigan Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Almond Spritz Cookies
images.description: These almond-flavored cookies can be left plain or decorated with colored sugar and frosting. In our house, it just wouldn't be Christmas without them.—Tanya Hart, Muncie, Indiana Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Lemon Snowflakes
images.description: Four ingredients is all it takes to whip up these delightful cookies.—Linda Barry, Dianna, Texas Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Jolly Ginger Reindeer Cookies
images.description: I made gingerbread cookies for years before realizing my gingerbread-man cutter becomes a reindeer when turned upside down. They’re super crispy and fun! —Sue Gronholz, Beaver Dam, Wisconsin Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Italian Pignoli Cookies
images.description: Cookies are the crown jewels of Italian confections. I can’t let a holiday go by without baking these traditional almond cookies rolled in mild pine nuts.—Maria Regakis, Somerville, Massachusetts Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Fig & Almond Cookies
images.description: In our family, holiday cookies—like these nutty fig ones—are a big deal. I'm so proud to be passing on this Italian tradition to my two boys. —Angela Lemoine, Howell, New Jersey Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Whipped Shortbread
images.description: This version of shortbread melts in your mouth. Mostly I make it for the holidays, but I'll also prepare it year-round for wedding showers and ladies' teas. —Jane Ficiur, Bow Island, Alberta Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Italian Christmas Cookies
images.description: "A single batch of these mouthwatering cookies is never enough," attests Doris Marshall of Strasburg, Pennsylvania. "I usually make one to give away and two more to keep at home. Adding ricotta cheese to the batter makes the morsels extra moist."—Doris Marshall, Strasburg, Pennsylvania Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Touch-of-Gold Christmas Trees
images.description: You can decorate these pretty Christmas trees with other types of sprinkles. And the filling makes the cookies special and so delicious! —Linda Sweet, Cornwall, New York Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Fruitcake Christmas Cookies
images.description: As holiday gifts, these rich fruit-and-nut filled cookies are pretty and practical. Make them ahead—the taste actually gets better over time! —Julia Funkhouser, Carson, Iowa Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Callahan Christmas Wreaths
images.description: When my family asked for good old Norwegian wreath cookies, I studied several recipes for ideas, then added my own special touches. — Cassidy Callahan, Fitchburg, Massachusetts Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

items.shortTitle: 30 Classic Christmas Cookies

items.title: 25 Days of Christmas Cocktails (and Mocktails!)
items.abstract: Make this your jolliest holiday season ever with these Christmas cocktails and merry mocktails!
items.author: jambrose

images.title: Cranberry-Jalapeno Martini
images.description: I describe this cocktail as slightly tart, a little sassy and completely delicious. I make a big batch when I'm hosting a party because it tends to disappear quickly. Garnish with fresh mint and cranberries for an extra-special touch. —Kelli Haetinger, Virginia Beach, Virginia Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Holiday Peppermint Mocha
images.description: Make spirits bright with a minty mocha to share under the mistletoe or around the piano. I’ve also stirred in coffee liqueur instead of peppermint. —Lauren Brien-Wooster, South Lake Tahoe, California Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Sparkling Celebration Punch
images.description: Every celebration deserves a gorgeous punch like this one – fruity, bubbly and icy cold. We garnish the punch bowl with slices of oranges, lemons or limes. —Sharon Tipton, Winter Garden, Florida Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Pomegranate Cosmo
images.description: Every soiree needs a signature drink. Sugar dresses up this simple cosmo that lets you enjoy a cozy evening with friends and still shake things up. —Taste of Home Test Kitchen Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Champagne Cocktail
images.description: This amber drink is a champagne twist on the traditional old-fashioned. Try it with extra-dry champagne. —Taste of Home Test Kitchen, Greendale, Wisconsin Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Sparkling Peach Bellinis
images.description: Folks will savor the subtle peach flavor in this elegant brunch beverage. — Taste of Home Test Kitchen Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: White Chocolate Brandy Alexander
images.description: This brandied white cocoa is a wonderful drink to warm up with after coming in from the cold. Whipped topping and chocolate shavings make special finishing touches. —Sharon Delaney-Chronis, South Milwaukee, Wisconsin Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: White Christmas Sangria
images.description: This punch has a pleasant fruity flavor. It's not too sweet so everyone will enjoy it! —Taste of Home Test Kitchen Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Homemade Limoncello
images.description: In Jenny Nelson's tale, Georgia's Kitchen, professional chef, Georgia, hones her culinary skills in the Italian countryside. Pair the book with a bottle of this homemade Limoncello, which is as good if not better than store bought. After all, the after-dinner liqueur is considered the national drink of Italy.— Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Holiday Wassail
images.description: This richly colored beverage tastes of Christmastime.—Lucy Meyring, Walden, Colorado Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Peppermint White Hot Chocolate
images.description: My soothing white hot chocolate is a great warm-up after a wintry day spent sledding or ice skating. Or include it as a festive addition to brunch or an afternoon tea party. —Darlene Brenden, Salem, Oregon Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Poinsettia
images.description: This pinkish concoction adds a festive twist to your party—whether it's for Christmas, New Years or even Valentine's Day. —Taste of Home Test Kitchen Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Caramel-Chai Tea Latte
images.description: Inspired by the spicy chai drinks served at coffee shops, I whipped up a caramel-drizzled latte I can enjoy at home anytime. —Katelyn Kelly, Perryville, Maryland Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Cranberry Orange Mimosas
images.description: Mimosas are just so elegant for Sunday brunch. My recipe uses tart cranberry juice to balance the sweetness of champagne and orange juice. —Shannon Stephens, Lake in the Hills, Illinois Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Slow Cooker Cider
images.description: There's no last-minute rush when you slowly simmer this punch. —Alpha Wilson, Roswell, New Mexico Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Hot Buttered Rum
images.description: “I received this recipe from a friend over 30 years ago, and I think of her every winter when I stir up a batch of this delightful mix. It keeps well in the freezer.” —Joyce Moynihan, Lakeville, Minnesota Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Cranberry Pomegranate Margaritas
images.description: I came up with this beverage to serve at holiday celebrations for a festive twist to a traditional margarita. It's light and refreshing, and super pretty with frozen cranberries floating in the cocktail. It would also look beautiful with sugar crystals around the rim of glass. —Mindie Hilton, Susanville, California Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Apple Brandy
images.description: I spend a lot of time developing recipes for the many fruits and vegetables we grow on our farm. In this creation, brandy is enhanced with apples and spices for a delightful drink.—Deanna Seippel, Lancaster, Wisconsin Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Bella Basil Raspberry Tea
images.description: Beautiful basil and fresh raspberries lend bright color and refreshing flavor to this grown-up iced tea. You’ll love the fun fizz and make-ahead convenience for parties. —Laurie Bock, Lynden, Washington Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Butterscotch Mulled Cider
images.description: Five minutes of preparation results in a dynamite slow-cooked drink. You’ll love the sweet taste of butterscotch and apple in this delightful cider. —Karen Mack, Webster, New York Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Cranberry-Orange Sangria
images.description: Letting this sangria sit in the fridge overnight improves the fruitiness, making it the perfect do-ahead drink for a party. It's also nice with a splash of brandy. —Maria Regakis, Somerville, Massachusetts Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Vanilla Citrus Cider
images.description: My mom used to make cider for the holidays, so I based my citrusy-vanilla variation on her recipe. I think it hits the spot! The longer the cider simmers, the stronger the flavors will be.—Kristin Weglarz, Bremerton, Washington Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Mimosa Floats
images.description: Everyone needs a little treat at brunch! I wanted to kick things up a notch, so I added a scoop of ice cream and some chocolate to my mimosas.—Amy Lents, Grand Forks, North Dakota Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Raspberry Merry
images.description: Here's a lighter cocktail with a festive merry look and flavor! —HEALTHY COOKING TEST KITCHEN Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Cider Wassail Punch
images.description: Cinnamon, cloves, apple cider and cranberry juice blend together to create a wonderful drink with an aroma to match. If you don’t have a percolator, simmer this drink on the stove and strain well before serving. —Sharon Tipton, Orlando, Florida Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

items.shortTitle: 25 Days of Christmas Cocktails and Mocktails

items.title: 150 of Our Best Christmas Cookie Recipes
items.abstract: Gingerbread, peppermint and meringue, oh my! Get the ultimate guide to Christmas cookies with this round up of the most amazing 150 recipes. Bake up a few dozen this holiday season to make friends, family and Santa extra jolly.
items.author: Caroline Stanko

images.title: Buttery Spritz Cookies
images.description: These tender little cookies are very eye-catching on my Christmas cookie tray. The dough is easy to work with, so it's fun to make these into a variety of festive shapes. —Beverly Launius, Sandwich, Illinois Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Chocolate Reindeer Cookies
images.description: Add a touch of whimsy to your holiday spread with these chocolaty treats. They're perfect for getting little ones involved. —Taste of Home Test Kitchen Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Holiday Cutout Cookies
images.description: The only limit to these fun cutouts is your cookie cutter collection and your imagination! If you prefer crisp cookies, sprinkle with colored sugar before baking and skip the frosting. —Anne Grisham, Henderson, Nevada Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Chocolate-Strawberry Pretzel Cookies
images.description: Every year I try to come up with a new recipe, and this is one that's been requested over and over. Who would guess how good pretzels are in cookies?.—Isabel Minunni, Poughkeepsie, New York Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Gingerbread Men Cookies
images.description: No holiday cookie platter would be complete without gingerbread men! This is a tried-and-true recipe I'm happy to share with you. —Mitzi Sentiff, Annapolis, Maryland Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Hot Chocolate Peppermint Cookies
images.description: This is a variation of the cookies my mother made when I was growing up. Now my 13-year-old daughter and I bake them together. They’re always a huge hit! The taste is like rich hot chocolate baked into a scrumptious cookie. —Larry Piklor, Johnsburg, Illinois Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Gooey Caramel-Topped Gingersnaps
images.description: Making these cookies is therapeutic for me. I often watch a movie while I put them together. I take a lot of cookies to fundraisers, and these gingersnaps are quite popular. If you'd like, you can make variations by changing the cookie base or varying the nuts. —Deirdre Cox, Kansas City, Missouri Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Lemon Shortbread Trees
images.description: Here's a fun holiday recipe children can help with. And no cookie cutters are needed! I just shape the dough into a triangular log, refrigerate it and cut it into tree-shaped slices to bake and decorate. Broken pretzel sticks form the tree trunks. —Phyllis Schmalz, Kansas City, Kansas Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Butterscotch Eggnog Stars
images.description: These yellow star-shaped cookies with a "stained-glass" center are almost too pretty to eat! But they have a rich eggnog flavor that is irresistible. Although they take a little time and patience to prepare, they're worth every minute! —Cheryl Hemmer, Swansea, Illinois Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Pecan Roll-Ups
images.description: This recipe is so delicious and is sure to become a favorite of your family. The pecans make them so rich.—Lee B. Roberts, Racine, Wisconsin Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Italian Holiday Cookies
images.description: Many of our holiday traditions center around the foods my mother made while I was growing up. These cookies, which we called "Strufoli", bring back wonderful memories. —Sue Seymour, Valatie, New York Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Chocolate Mint Dreams
images.description: Since chocolate-mint is my favorite flavor combination, I sometimes eat these dainty shortbread-like treats by the dozen. But I manage to save some for guests because they make my cookie trays look so elegant. -Anne Revers Omaha, Nebraska Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Snowman Cookies
images.description: Wrap these chocolate-topped snowmen in colored tissue and place them inside holiday containers. Like real snowmen, they disappear fast! —Betty Tabb, Mifflintown, Pennsylvania Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Cherry Almond Snowdrops
images.description: As soon as I was old enough, I helped make these distinctive almond cookies. You can freeze the dough, so they’re perfect for the busy holidays. —Trisha Kruse, Eagle, Idaho Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Honey-Nut Christmas Cookies
images.description: My sons, Aaron and Zach, adore these at Christmastime and like to warm them in the microwave before they eat them. They’re well worth the time they take. —Glenda Herz, Lawrence, Nebraska Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Glazed Ornament Cookies
images.description: A few ingredients and a tube of cookie dough make these luscious treats a breeze to whip up. The beautiful swirled colors will look gorgeous on your holiday cookie tray! —Taste of Home Test Kitchen Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Pistachio-Walnut Cookies
images.description: I've had this cookie in my rotation for many years, and it never fails to please. I prefer pistachio nuts and black walnuts for sprinkling over the cookie cutouts, but it's fine to use whatever nut you prefer.—Lorraine Caland, Shuniah, Ontario Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Chocolate Linzer Cookies
images.description: Living in the town of North Pole, it's no surprise that I enjoy Christmas baking! My mom and I used to make these cookies together. Now that I am married and living in Alaska, I love to bake them for my own family. They remind me of home. —Heather Peters, North Pole, Alaska Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Citrus Gingerbread Cookies
images.description: Orange and lemon zest give gingerbread cutouts a refreshing twist. Brushing a honey glaze over the top adds a subtle shine and extra touch of sweetness. —Monique Hooker, DeSoto, WI Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Grandma's Raspberry Rugelach
images.description: I remember sitting down on the couch in my great-grandmother's house with a pad and pen as she told me each ingredient and measurement for her special rugelach. Some of the ingredients are different from the typical version. —Dalya Rubin, Boca Raton, Florida Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Holly Berry Cookies
images.description: What would Christmas be without overflowing tins of cookies? These festive filled cookies are the all time favorites of my family. Back when our children were small, we began baking them the day after Halloween and put them away in the freezer. Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Lemon Snowdrops
images.description: I save my snowdrop cookies for special occasions. The crunchy, buttery sandwich cookie has a puckery lemon filling. —Bernice Martinoni, Petaluma, CA Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Lime Christmas Tea Cookies
images.description: Brighten your holiday cookie tray with these tangy frosted fir tree that are flecked with pistachios and flavored with lime juice and vanilla. The festive treats are almost too pretty to eat! —Mary Ann Taday, East Lyme, Connecticut Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Cherry Chocolate Chunk Cookies
images.description: These rich, fudgy cookies are chewy and studded with tangy dried cherries. It’s a good thing the recipe makes only a small batch, because we eat them all in one night! —Trisha Kruse, Eagle, Idaho Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Cranberry Pecan Tassies
images.description: A traditional pecan tassie is a small tart with nuts. This holiday version adds cranberries. How festive! —Peggy West, Georgetown, Delaware Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Nanny's Fruitcake Cookies
images.description: My grandmother always made a holiday fruitcake. I turned her recipe into cookies that are perfect any time, especially with a cup of tea. —Amanda Digges, South Windsor, Connecticut Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Frosted Anise Sugar Cookies
images.description: These soft, cake-like cookies have a pleasant anise flavor that's distinct but not overpowering. I add red and green sprinkles for Christmas, but you could decorate them to suit any occasion.—Janice Eanni, Willowick, Ohio Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Santa Claus Sugar Cookies
images.description: I've used this recipe for almost 40 years and love it because it's a little different than most. My mom always made Santa cookies, and we'd put them into little clear bags tied with ribbon to hang on the tree.—Ann Bush, Colorado City, Colorado Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Chocolate-Dipped Meringue Sandwich Cookies
images.description: These light, airy morsels are twice as nice with two meringue cookies and velvety ganache in between. —Donna Pochoday-Stelmach, Morristown, New Jersey Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Chocolate Cutout Cookies
images.description: I love gingerbread cookies, but my grandchildren don't like the ginger flavor. Now I use chocolate and watch them smile as they take that first bite. —Nancy Murphy, Oneonta, New York Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Cherry Snowballs
images.description: A juicy maraschino cherry is the fun surprise tucked inside these special cookies. My mom was inspired to create this by a recipe she clipped out of the newspaper more than 30 years ago. —Evy Adams, West Seneca, New York Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Peppermint Biscotti
images.description: Dipped in melted chocolate and rolled in crushed peppermint candy, this flavorful biscotti is a favorite. It's one of the many sweets I make for Christmas. —Paula Marchesi, Lenhartsville, Pennsylvania Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Vanilla-Butter Sugar Cookies
images.description: While I usually bake these cookies for Christmas, I'll also make them at Valentine's Day (in the shape of hearts, with messages written in frosting), at Thanksgiving (shaped like turkeys), at Halloween (pumpkins), etc. Children like to help out with the decorating. —Cynthia Ettel, Hutchinson, Minnesota Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Folded Hazelnut Cookies
images.description: We first made these cookies when my boys were small, and they would always end up covered in flour and with Nutella on their faces. Such good memories! —Paula Marchesi, Lenhartsville, Pennsylvania Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Crinkle-Top Chocolate Cookies
images.description: When I baked these moist, fudgy cookies for the first time, my three preschool children went wild over them! But I like them because they're lower in fat and easy to mix and bake. —Maria Groff, Ephrata, Pennsylvania Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Red Velvet Peppermint Thumbprints
images.description: Red velvet cookies and cakes are so pretty, but I always wish they had a bigger flavor. I infused these thumbprints with a peppermint pop. —Priscilla Yee, Concord, California Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Linzer Tarts
images.description: With a creamy chocolate and hazelnut filling, these decadent Christmas cookies look and taste amazing. Guests will never guess how relatively easy they are to make. Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Scottish Shortbread
images.description: Scottish settlers first came to this area over 150 years ago. My mother herself was Scottish, and—as with most of my favorite recipes—she passed this on to me. I make a triple batch of it each year at Christmas, to enjoy and as gifts. —Rose Mabee, Selkirk, Manitoba Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Peanut Butter Christmas Mice
images.description: With their red licorice tails, candy noses and peanut ears, these chewy "mice" were always a hit at classroom parties. My children are in their teens now, but they still ask me to make these cookies for the holidays. -Nancy Rowse Bella Vista, Arkansas Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Neapolitan Cookies
images.description: My sister shared the recipe for these tricolor treats several years ago. The crisp cookies are fun to eat one section at a time or with all three in one bite. —Jan Mallo, White Pigeon, Michigan Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: No-Bake Christmas Wreath Treats
images.description: Cornflakes take the place of traditional rice cereal in these sweet no-bake treats from our Test Kitchen. Dressed up with green food coloring and red candies, they're a fun addition to cookie platters and dessert buffets. Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Coconut Cranberry Yummies
images.description: When my husband came home from the grocery store with six bags of fresh cranberries, I launched a full scale effort to creatively use them all. Bursting with tart cranberry and sweet coconut flavor, these tasty bites are my favorite result from that experiment. Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Mint Chocolate Wafers
images.description: My grandmother gave me a cookbook stuffed with recipes. This is a slight twist on one of the first—and best—recipes I made from the book. It's best to store these in the refrigerator. —Mary Murphy, Evansville, Indiana Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Roly-Poly Santas
images.description: I tuck one of these fanciful Santas into every gift cookie tray I make. They're a guaranteed hit with kids—young and old. And I like that they're not too difficult to assemble. —Mrs. Andrew Syer, Oak Ridge, Missouri Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Pecan Meltaways
images.description: These sweet, nutty treats are a tradition in our house at Christmastime, but they are great any time of the year. —Alberta McKay, Bartlesville, Oklahoma Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Chocolate-Dipped Cranberry Cookies
images.description: These pretty pink cookies always turn out so tender. They are the hit of my holiday! —Barbara Nowakowski, North Tonawanda, New York Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Snickerdoodles
images.description: The history of this whimsically named treat is widely disputed, but the popularity of this classic cinnamon-sugar-coated cookie is undeniable! —Taste of Home Test Kitchen Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Grandma's Star Cookies
images.description: My husband's grandma would only make these butter cutouts with a star cookie cutter. I use various shapes for celebrations throughout the year. —Jenny Brown, West Lafayette, Indiana Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Fruit-Filled Spritz Cookies
images.description: From the first time I baked these cookies, they've been a lip-smacking success. Old-fashioned and attractive, they make a perfect holiday pastry. I'm the grandmother of six and stay active with a German folk dance group. —Ingeborg Keith, Newark, Delaware Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Chocolate-Nut Pinwheel Cookies
images.description: As a little girl, I made these with my mother every Christmas. Now I make them every year with my daughters-in-law, daughters and grandchildren!—Sedonie Zeitler, Luxemburg, Wisconsin Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Almond Raspberry Stars
images.description: The first Christmas that I baked these, I ended up quickly making a second batch! The whole family enjoyed them. —Darlene Weaver, Lebanon, Pennsylvania Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Kipplens
images.description: My Great-Aunt Hilda makes this recipe every Christmas, and everybody loves them! Kipplens taste a lot like Mexican wedding cakes, but I like my aunt's version better.—Susan Bohannon, Kokomo, Indiana Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Gingerbread Cookies with Buttercream Icing
images.description: When it’s time to start the cookie-baking season, this recipe always kicks off the festivities. My mother-in-law first shared it with me, but it’s too good to keep to myself! You can tint the buttery icing a cheery pink or green and pipe it on with a decorating tip. —Ann Scherzer, Anacortes, Washington Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Cashew Cookies
images.description: Some "dairy" merry snacking is guaranteed when you pass out these cashew-packed goodies! I found the recipe in a flyer promoting dairy products years ago. It's been this farm wife's standby ever since. —June Lindquist, Hammond, Wisconsin Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Hidden Mint Morsels
images.description: Is it a cookie or a candy? No matter which answer folks choose, they find these minty morsels yummy. The recipe makes so much that you can whip up tons of gifts at once. —Adina Skilbred, Prairie du Sac, Wisconsin Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Holiday Sugar Cookies
images.description: Katie Koziolek of Hartland, Minnesota adds a hint of lemon to these delightful sugar cookies. For make-ahead convenience, freeze the dough up to three months, then thaw in the fridge before baking and decorating them. Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Candied Fruit Cookies
images.description: "These no-fuss drop cookies are both nutty and fruity, so they're always a hit at holiday time," notes busy baker Florence Monson of Denver, Colorado. Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Snow Angel Cookies
images.description: Get a little snow at the holidays, no matter where you are. Head to the kitchen and bake a batch of angel cookies swirled with heavenly frosting. —Carolyn Moseley, Dayton, Ohio Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Cannoli Wafer Sandwiches
images.description: My family loves to visit a local Italian restaurant that has a wonderful dessert buffet. The cannolis are among our favorites, so I just had to come up with a quicker recipe of my own. They are best if served the same day so the wafers stay crisp. Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Christmas Lights Cookies
images.description: What better way to brighten chilly winter days than with light-shaped cookies? My classic dough recipe has been a holiday tradition in our family for years. —Carolyn Moseley, Dayton, Ohio Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Reindeer Track Cookies
images.description: I loved finding deer tracks in snow when I was a kid. One day I was looking at coffee beans, and I realized they look like little hoof prints. That's how I came up with this fun recipe.—Crystal Schlueter, Northglenn, Colorado Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Cranberry Cookies with Browned Butter Glaze
images.description: I won a baking contest with these chunky glazed cookies that are so easy, even novice bakers can pull them off. What makes them special? Fresh cranberries. —Laurie Cornett, Charlevoix, Michigan Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Peppermint Twist Kisses
images.description: As rosy as Santa's cheeks, these merry morsels with chocolate kisses on top are a delightful yuletide favorite and one of my most-requested recipes. —Traci Wynne, Denver, Pennsylvania Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Italian Christmas Cookies
images.description: "A single batch of these mouthwatering cookies is never enough," attests Doris Marshall of Strasburg, Pennsylvania. "I usually make one to give away and two more to keep at home. Adding ricotta cheese to the batter makes the morsels extra moist."—Doris Marshall, Strasburg, Pennsylvania Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Gingerbread Sandwich Trees
images.description: Fun and festive, these cookie sandwich trees will be a huge hit with kids of all ages. They're a super-cute holiday treat! —Steve Foy, Kirkwood, Missouri Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Buttery Ganache Cookie Cups
images.description: Our family wanted to share our love of ganache-filled cupcakes, so we made them into cookies. Even better: we bake the cookies in muffin cups, fill with ganache, and get the best of both worlds!—Adela Srinivasan, Parker, Colorado Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Triple-Chocolate Peppermint Treats
images.description: Santa is sure to stop by your house if you leave these minty chocolate cookies waiting for him. They're quick and easy for the whole family to make together. —Teresa Ralston, New Albany, Ohio Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Mom's Buttermilk Cookies
images.description: I treasure my mother’s recipe for these comforting cookie pillows. The tender treats are topped with thick frosting and a sprinkling of chopped walnuts. —Jane Darling, Simi Valley, California Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Berry-Almond Sandwich Cookies
images.description: Almond shortbread cookies cradle a delightful berry filling for this Christmas cookie favorite. The recipe is undeniably good. —Helga Schlape, Florham Park, New Jersey Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Holly Wreaths
images.description: Meet the Cook: I've never come across another spritz cookie like this - one calling for cream cheese as an ingredient. That helps to keep these wreaths moist a long time, while also adding a delicious flavor. Our home is on a couple of acres out in the country. We're retired, with four children and seven grandchildren. -Dee Lein, Longmont, Colorado Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Peppermint Kisses
images.description: "These are fun, refreshing and low in fat!" notes field editor Lynn Bernstetter of Lake Elmo, Minnesota. Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Eggnog Cookies
images.description: This cookie's flavor fits right into the holiday spirit—pick your favorite cookie cutter shapes to make them even more festive! —Myra Innes, Auburn, Kansas Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Pistachio Buttons
images.description: This cookie recipe makes a big batch, which comes in handy during the holidays. The green center adds a festive touch. —Nella Parker, Hersey, Michigan Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Gooey Butter Cookies
images.description: As a native of St. Louis, I wanted to make a cookie version of the famous gooey butter cake. And although many gooey butter cake recipes use a cake mix, my cookies are made from scratch.—Julia Nouss, Richmond, Virginia Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Sugar Doves
images.description: "I enjoy making these beautiful cookies and I love to spend a cold evening decorating them." Pretty little sugar doves are sure to get you into the holiday spirit! - Peggy Preston, Fenton, Iowa Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Hazelnut Yule Logs
images.description: Besides being irresistibly nutty, these travel well and are a snap to make! — Barbara Burge, Los Gatos, California Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Cream Cheese Spritz
images.description: A hint of orange and cinnamon highlights these Christmastime classics. I like to add colorful sprinkles before baking them. The recipe is from a booklet that came with a cookie press in the 1950s...and I still have the press! Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Homemade Chocolate Shortbread
images.description: THIS RECIPE has been in my files for a long time...probably from when I first learned to bake. Any chocolate lover will like these melt-in-your-mouth cookies. I make them year-round with variations. They're even richer with a thin coat of icing or as a sandwich cookie with frosting in the middle. -Sarah Bueckert, Austin, Manitoba Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Salted Caramel Cookie Cups
images.description: When I brought these salty sweet cookies to a potluck, I overheard people talking about how wonderful they were. I'm not sure if it was the cookie, the caramel or the chocolate that they loved best.—Priscilla Yee, Concord, California Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Callahan Christmas Wreaths
images.description: When my family asked for good old Norwegian wreath cookies, I studied several recipes for ideas, then added my own special touches. — Cassidy Callahan, Fitchburg, Massachusetts Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Easy Mint Thins
images.description: My friends often try to guess the ingredients, but I never tell them how simple they are to make. They taste just like the Girl Scout cookie, and they're perfect for Christmas and bake sales. —Jennifer Setser, Morgantown, Indiana Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Elf Cookies
images.description: A sweet frosting glaze, colorful candies and well-placed almond slices turn these sugar cookie diamonds into a big batch of Santa’s helpers. TIP: Bake a batch of the adorable elves as a classroom treat or use a few to brighten each of your cookie trays. Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Peanut Butter Spritz Fingers
images.description: My family loves these cookies because they satisfy the need for chocolate and for something crunchy, sweet and nutty, all in just one bite! —Irma Lowery, Reedsburg, Wisconsin Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Red & Green Pinwheels
images.description: My mom used to make these cookies every Christmas, and I still love them. They are so colorful. You can use different food coloring for different seasons.—Jill Heatwole, Pittsville, Maryland Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Chocolate Walnut Crescents
images.description: I use a round cookie cutter to form the crescent shapes for these nutty favorites. They're so pretty sprinkled with sugar and drizzled with chocolate. Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Gingerbread Cookies with Lemon Frosting
images.description: When I spread these spicy gingerbread rounds with my lemony cream-cheese frosting, I knew I had a hit. Cardamom and allspice add a hint of chai tea flavor. —Aysha Schurman, Ammon, Idaho Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Classic Candy Cane Butter Cookies
images.description: To make cookies that look like candy canes, we color half the dough in classic red and twist away. They're fun to hang on the side of a coffee mug, or you can devour them on their own. —Shannon Roum, Milwaukee, Wisconsin Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Spiced German Cookies
images.description: These buttery spice cookies are a cross between sugar cookies and gingerbread, creating the best of both worlds. —April Drasin, Van Nuys, California Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Easy Chocolate Gingerbread Cutouts
images.description: I have many wonderful memories making these chocolaty cookies with my family during the Christmas season.—Debbie Rowe, Lexington, Kentucky Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Marzipan Cups with Currant Jelly
images.description: These bite-size beauties look and taste gourmet, but they're easy to make and boast a delicate almond flavor. The hidden jelly surprise and pretty nut accent make them a nice addition to any treats tray. You can make them in advance and freeze them for up to three months, if you like. —Lorraine Caland, Shuniah, Ontario Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Cranberry Shortbread Stars
images.description: My family loves shortbread and I love cranberries, so I decided to put the two together. The star shape is a festive addition to my holiday cookie tray. —Sonya Labbe, West Hollywood, California Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Italian Honey Clusters
images.description: My mother made these treats flavored with cinnamon and anise for neighbors, teachers and anyone who stopped by. Make sure the honey doesn’t boil longer than a minute or it could burn.—Sarah Knoblock, Hyde Park, IN Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Greek Butter Crescents
images.description: I had to bake something from my heritage for school. I made these little drops of heaven called kourabiedes. —Rebecca Sprague, St. Louis, Missouri Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Silver Bells
images.description: My mom and grandma are known for their signature Christmas cookies. I decided to create my own, inspired by one of my favorite Christmas songs. Edible shimmer dust gives them their iconic shine. Look for the dust in the cake decorating section of craft or grocery stores. —Crystal Schlueter, Northglenn, Colorado Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Gingerbread Yule Logs
images.description: I was never fond of gingerbread until I rolled it up with Nutella. These logs make a fabulous addition to any cookie platter.—Terri Gilson, Calgary, AB Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Gingerbread Snowflakes
images.description: Cutting my favorite gingerbread cookie dough into snowflake shapes and decorating them with white icing was ideal for my theme get-together. I save these crunchy treats to enjoy on the way home from our Christmas tree outing. -Shelly Rynearson, Oconomowoc, Wisconsin Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Molasses Cookie Mix
images.description: These spicy, old-fashioned treats are sure to be a hit with your family and friends. For holiday gift giving, I put a batch of this cookie mix in an attractive basket along with the recipe and a festive tea towel. —Barbara Stewart, Portland, Connecticut Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Holiday Cornflake Cookies
images.description: I can't seem to make enough of these cornflake wreaths around the holidays. The cookies firm up quickly, so you'll need to place the Red Hots right away. —Kathleen Hedger, Fairview Heights, Illinois Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Fruit 'n' Spice Rounds
images.description: While I was looking for a way to use up an abundance of dates, I came across this recipe. Made with raisins, walnuts and a delectable lemon glaze, these quickly became a family favorite. —Allison Bell, Helena, Montana Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Walnut-Filled Pillows
images.description: These tender cookie pillows, filled with a delicious walnut mixture, are my husband's favorite. He says it wouldn't be Christmas without them. —Nancy Kostrej, Canonsburg, Pennsylvania Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Molasses Crackle Cookies
images.description: You can treat yourself to one or two of my crackle cookies without any pang of guilt. Most molasses cookies are loaded with butter and have way too much sugar, but not mine. You would never know these are so low in fat.— Jean L. Ecos, Hartland, Wisconsin Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Jeweled Cookies
images.description: Candied fruits give a stained-glass look to these cookies that taste like shortbread. —Ruth Ann Stelfox, Raymond, Alberta Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Gingerbread Snow Globe
images.description: I make a big batch of these gingerbreads every Christmas to give to co-workers and family. For a festive decoration, arrange cookies in a large clear jar to look like a snow globe. —Kelly Kirby, Westville, Nova Scotia Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Frosted Maple Pyramids
images.description: The cute shape of these cookies makes them a splendid sight on a Christmas cookie tray. You could use star-shaped cookie cutters in place of the round ones. Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Nuts-About-You Cookie Sticks
images.description: These cookies make a fancy meal finale that couldn’t be quicker to whip up. Start with purchased Pirouette cookies, dip in a rich creamy chocolate and peanut-butter coating, dust with nuts or sprinkles, serve with your favorite after-dinner beverage. —Taste of Home Test Kitchen, Milwaukee, Wisconsin Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Raspberry Almonettes
images.description: Sometimes that “missing ingredient” idea comes to me in my sleep, and I have to jot it down. The surprising filling in these cookies makes them fun to bake and even more fun to eat! —Angela Sheridan, Opdyke, Illinois Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Santa Claus Cookies
images.description: Store-bought peanut butter sandwich cookies become jolly Santas with white chocolate, colored sugar, mini chips and red-hot candies. —Mary Kaufenberg, Shakopee, Minnesota Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Peanut Butter Chippers
images.description: The smell of peanut butter and chocolate always brings my cookie-hungry family running to the kitchen. The recipe is so quick and easy, I often stir up a batch while making dinner. —Pat Doerflinger, Centerview, Missouri Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Cherry Kiss Cookies
images.description: Topped with a chocolate kiss, these cherry-flavored cookies look super cute on a dessert tray. Share them with family and friends. —Joy Yurk, Grafton, Wisconsin Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Touch-of-Gold Christmas Trees
images.description: You can decorate these pretty Christmas trees with other types of sprinkles. And the filling makes the cookies special and so delicious! —Linda Sweet, Cornwall, New York Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Peppermint Meltaways
images.description: This recipe is very pretty and festive-looking on a cookie platter. I often cover a plate of these meltaways with red or green plastic wrap and a bright holiday bow in one corner. And yes, they really do melt in your mouth! —Denise Wheeler, Newaygo, Michigan Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Nice 'n' Soft Sugar Cookies
images.description: My family’s all-time favorite Christmas cookie has had a million shapes over the years. Little ones have fun making their own icing designs. — Cathy Hall, Lyndhurst, Virginia Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Holiday Rum Balls
images.description: I use this recipe for special occasions with my wonderful family and friends. They're so easy to make and pack a festive rum punch. — Diane Duschanek, Council Bluffs, Iowa Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Dipped Sandwich Cookies
images.description: With a lemon filling and chocolate coating, these buttery sandwich cookies are often requested at my house, particularly for special occasions. —Jane Delahoyde, Poughkeepsie, New York Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Tender Italian Sugar Cookies
images.description: These traditional Italian cookies are moist and tender. —Weda Mosellie, Phillipsburg, New Jersey Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Meringue Candy Canes
images.description: These red-and-white striped treats get lots of compliments for their cute looks and minty taste. The seasonal confections are easy to make and so light that they melt in your mouth! —Anne Lindway of Indianapolis, Indiana Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Sugar Cookies
images.description: This sugar cookie dates back to a Swedish woman born in 1877! Her daughter, Esther Davis, shared the recipe with me and she came up with all the exact measurements, since the original cookies were mixed by feel and taste. These are my favorite cookies and I hope they'll become yours as well. —Helen Wallis, Vancouver, Washington Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Pinwheel Cookies
images.description: These pretty pinwheel cookies have tempting swirly layers of orange and chocolate. I really mess up my kitchen whenever I bake a batch, but the smiles on the faces of family and friends enjoying them make it all worthwhile. — Paulette Morgan, Moorhead, Minnesota Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Snowman Christmas Cookies
images.description: Get the kids in on the action when you make these cheesecakey cookies—just roll away. The snowmen look adorable on a cookie tray. —Cathy Medley, Clyde, Ohio Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Almond Bonbon Cookies
images.description: These bonbons remind me of England, with a touch of America. Dip cooled cookies into one frosting or each side into different frostings. Have fun adding any kind of sprinkle toppings you like.— Teri Lee Rasey, Cadillac, Michigan Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Pistachio Cream Cheese Cookies
images.description: My son-in-law is a big fan of pistachios. He looks forward to these buttery cookies at holiday time, but I make them for him more than just once a year. —Lily Julow, Lawrenceville, Georgia Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Snowman Butter Cutouts
images.description: I have fond memories of baking and frosting these cutout cookies with my mom. Now I carry on the tradition with my kids. It's a messy but fun day!—Sandy Nace, Greensburg, Kansas Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Holiday Cookie Dough
images.description: We created this make-ahead dough recipe to help ease the stress of the Christmas baking season. The buttery cookies are sure to melt in your mouth. —Taste of Home Test Kitchen Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Chai Tea Sandwich Cookies
images.description: You’ll love these cookies filled with a dreamy chai-infused ganache. They’re great after a meal, with a cup of tea, as a breakfast treat—or anytime at all. —Lauren Knoelke, Milwaukee, Wisconsin Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Holiday Shortbread Cookies
images.description: This special Christmas treat came to me from Scotland through a relative. I compared this recipe with one a friend makes, since her husband is of Scottish descent, and found this shortbread to be quite authentic. —Erma Hiltpold, Kerrville, Texas Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Tiny Tim Sandwich Cookies
images.description: When I was growing up, my mother and I created special Christmas memories in the kitchen preparing these cute, bite-size cookies. Vary the food coloring for holidays throughout the year. Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Chocolate Lebkuchen
images.description: Having lived in Germany, I try to keep my German cooking as authentic as possible. These lovely lebkuchen are a culinary Christmas custom. —Cathy Lemmon, Quinlan, Texas Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Spearmint Thins
images.description: No time to bake cookies from scratch? Create a tasty treat in little more than half an hour by doctoring butter-flavored crackers with vanilla chips and mint candies.—Kathleen Felton, Fairfax, Iowa Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Stacked Christmas Tree Cookies
images.description: Using prepared cookie dough gives you a nice head start to your own little forest of Christmas trees. Get the kids involved in this holiday craft to keep them busy making memories.—Sue Draheim, Waterford, Wisconsin Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Butterscotch Gingerbread Cookies
images.description: Every time I make these wonderful cookies, the spicy aroma takes me back to my childhood. I helped Mom make them and delivered them to neighbors. —Kara Cook, Elk Ridge, Utah Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Cranberry Port Cookies
images.description: This is my version of a recipe I tasted years ago—my family loves it. The flaky cookies are filled with a scrumptious combination of dried cranberries, cinnamon, lemon and a hint of port wine. —Leslie Forte, Oakhill, Virginia Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Scottie Cookies
images.description: These decked-out doggies are all bundled up in colorful sweaters for the holidays. The frosted sugar cookies are almost too adorable to eat! — Taste of Home Test Kitchen Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Apricot-Filled Sandwich Cookies
images.description: I bake these delightful cookies every year for Christmas and when I share a tray of my homemade treats with the faculty at school, these are always the first to disappear! I've even had requests to make them for wedding receptions.—Deb Lyon, Bangor, Pennsylvania Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Hungarian Walnut Cookies
images.description: As a child, I always looked forward to eating these goodies at Christmastime. Now I make them for my own family. —Sharon Kurtz, Emmaus, PA Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Holiday Reindeer Cookies
images.description: Gather 'round the tree on Christmas Eve and feast on these adorable reindeer cookies. If you listen closely, you might heard reindeer hoofs on the roof! —Taste of Home Test Kitchen Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Chocolate-Filled Cookies with Peppermint Frosting
images.description: Baking is one of the things I enjoy most about Christmas. These special cookies draw you in with candy-topped frosting and seal the deal with a chocolate center. —Deborah Puette, Lilburn, GA Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Crescent Chip Cookies
images.description: With their cute curved shape, crescents always make charming additions to a Christmas platter. I dip the cooled cookies in chocolate and sprinkle on walnuts. —Ann Eastman, Sacramento, California Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Meringue Santa Hats
images.description: My grandkids love it when I make meringues shaped like Santa hats. If they are here, they love to help—they like to put red glitter on the meringue and take such pride in knowing they have helped Grandma.—Bonnie Hawkins, Elkhorn, Wisconsin Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Fig & Almond Cookies
images.description: In our family, holiday cookies—like these nutty fig ones—are a big deal. I'm so proud to be passing on this Italian tradition to my two boys. —Angela Lemoine, Howell, New Jersey Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Cream Cheese Turtle Cups
images.description: Sometimes the best thing about a cookie is the memories made. My little girl and I love to make and eat these “turtles.” —Lesa Renner, Kingsport, Tennessee Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Cherry Cheese Windmills
images.description: These pretty cookies look fancy, but they are really not much work. They're perfect for any occasion. —Helen McGibbon, Downers Grove, Illinois Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Red Velvet White Chip Cookies
images.description: These cookies are soft, chewy and taste as good as they sound. The first time I baked them, I took them to an aunt's yard sale. Now they’re my go-to for any special event. —Samantha Gstalder, Montoursville, PA Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Cherry Pecan Dreams
images.description: Packed with fruit, nuts and vanilla chips, these goodies are sure to please. If you prefer, replace the cherries with cranberries or apricots. Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Thumbprint Butter Cookies
images.description: These buttery little rounds add beautiful color to a platter of treats. Fill the thumbprint in the center with any fruit preserves you like. —Taste of Home Test Kitchen Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Date Swirl Cookies
images.description: "My 3-year-old granddaughter nicknamed my mother 'Cookie Grandma' because she made wonderful cookies," shares Donna Grace of Clancy, Montana. "Mom made these crisp and chewy cookies every Christmas." Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Meringue Kisses
images.description: There's a nice chocolaty surprise inside these sweet kisses. They're my husband's top choice each Christmas.—Tami Henke, Lockport, Illinois Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Cranberry-White Chocolate Cookies
images.description: These are one of my favorite cookies to make for the holidays. I prepare a batch early in the holiday season and freeze them.—Sherry Conley, Noel Hants County, Nova Scotia Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Cranberry Slices
images.description: The holidays wouldn't be complete without a plateful of homemade cookies to give family and friends. Try these for gifts.—American Dairy Assoc, Stacy Duffy, Chicago, Illinois Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Hazelnut Dream Cookies
images.description: I sampled these goodies at a Bible study and knew from the first bite that I had to have the recipe. To my surprise, the rich cookies require just four ingredients. —Julie Peterson, Crofton, MD Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Apricot-Hazelnut Triangles
images.description: These crispy cookie treats can be changed up—try different nuts and jams, and dark or white chocolate depending on the holiday. —Johnna Johnson, Scottsdale, Arizona Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

items.shortTitle: 150 of the Best Christmas Cookies Ever

items.title: 40 Super Easy Casseroles to Throw Together for Dinner Tonight
items.abstract: A handful of ingredients, just a few steps and you've got dinner! These easy casserole recipes will be your saving grace on busy weeknights.
items.author: Tasteofhome

images.title: Baked Chops and Cottage Fries
images.description: Convenience items like frozen vegetables and a jar of cheese sauce make it a snap to assemble this comforting pork chop supper. It's a simple one-dish meal. —Gregg Voss, Emerson, Nebraska Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Contest-Winning Broccoli Chicken Casserole
images.description: This delicious twist on chicken divan came from an old boss, who gave the recipe to me when I got married. It’s quick, satisfying comfort food. —Jennifer Schlachter, Big Rock, Illinois Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Reuben Bread Pudding
images.description: Our Aunt Renee always brought this casserole to family picnics, and it became so popular that she started making two or three to bring. —Johnna Johnson, Scottsdale, Arizona Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Stuffing & Turkey Casserole
images.description: This is a plate full of love, comfort and goodness. —Debbie Fabre, Ft Myers, Florida Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Southwest Vegetarian Bake
images.description: This veggie-packed casserole hits the spot on chilly nights. But it's great any time I have a taste for Mexican food with all the fixings, too. —Patricia Gale, Monticello, Illinois Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Contest-Winning Chicken Wild Rice Casserole
images.description: While this special dish is perfect for a company dinner, it's also just too good not to make often for everyday family meals. We think it is very nice served with some crusty rolls or French bread. —Elizabeth Tokariuk, Lethbridge, Alberta Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Seafood Casserole
images.description: A family favorite, this rice casserole is stuffed with plenty of seafood and veggies. It's hearty, homey and so easy to make! —Nancy Billups Princeton, Iowa Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Taco Salad Casserole
images.description: This casserole tastes like a taco salad and is a breeze to assemble. I crush tortilla chips to form a bottom layer, then spread on refried beans, a spicy meat mixture and cheese. —Rhonda McKee, Greensburg, Kansas Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Chicken Amandine
images.description: With colorful green beans and pimientos, this attractive casserole is terrific for the holidays. This is true comfort food at its finest. —Kat Woolbright, Wichita Falls, Texas Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Rice-Stuffed Peppers
images.description: Mother used to fix this wonderful, easy dish when we had company. She was from a family of fantastic Cajun cooks, so our food was always well-seasoned. In Louisiana, rice is part of many meals. The cheese sauce sets these stuffed peppers apart from any others I've tried. —Lisa Easley, Longview, Texas Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Chili Mac Casserole
images.description: This cheesy casserole uses several of my family's favorite ingredients, including macaroni, kidney beans, tomatoes and cheese. Just add a green salad for a complete meal. —Marlene Wilson, Rolla, North Dakota Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Chicken and Swiss Stuffing Bake
images.description: I love to cook but just don't have much time. This casserole is both good and fast, which makes it my favorite kind of recipe. I serve it with a green salad. —Jena Coffey, Sunset Hills, Missouri Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Chicken Tortilla Bake
images.description: Mother frequently made this comforting casserole when I was growing up. Our family would scrape the pan clean. Chicken, cheese and zippy green chilies are a mouthwatering mix.—Jerri Moror, Rio Rancho, New Mexico Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Sauerkraut Casserole
images.description: Mom brewed her own sauerkraut and, of course, the cabbage was from our big farm garden! Blending the kraut with spicy sausage and apples was Mom's favorite way to fix it, and I still love this country dish. —Rosemary Pryor, Pasadena, Maryland Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Artichoke Ratatouille Chicken
images.description: I loaded all the fresh produce I could find into this speedy chicken dinner. Serve it on its own or over pasta. —Judy Armstrong, Prairieville, Louisiana Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Potluck Taco Casserole
images.description: This is the dish I take most often to potlucks, and the pan comes home empty every time. It has the irresistible taco taste that everybody craves. —Kim Stoller, Smithville, Ohio Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Penne and Smoked Sausage
images.description: My sausage pasta is a must-try dish. It just tastes so good when it’s hot and bubbly from the oven. The cheddar french-fried onions lend a cheesy, crunchy touch. —Margaret Wilson, Sun City, California Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Chicken Enchilada Bake
images.description: Your family is going to gobble up this cheesy, Southwestern chicken bake…and will ask for it again and again. It’s real comfort food! —Melanie Burns, Pueblo West, Colorado Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Chicken Noodle Casserole
images.description: Everyone who tries this comforting cheesy chicken casserole asks for the recipe. It's so simple to make that sometimes I feel like I'm cheating! —Kay Pederson, Yellville, Arkansas Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Tomato, Sausage & Cheddar Bread Pudding
images.description: This savory dish is the perfect excuse to have bread pudding as THE meal, not merely afterward as dessert. — Holly Jones, Kennesaw, Georgia Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Crunchy Almond Turkey Casserole
images.description: A special cousin shared the recipe for this comforting casserole. The almonds and water chestnuts give it a nice crunch. —Jill Black, Troy, Ontario Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Grandma's Rice Dish
images.description: My grandmother often made this casserole when I was young. I forgot about it until I found myself one day adding the same ingredients to leftover rice. The memories came flooding back, and I've made this recipe regularly since then. —Lorna Moore, Glendora, California Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Meatballs Sausage Dinner
images.description: One day I was having trouble deciding what to make for dinner. So I combined whatever was in the refrigerator and freezer! To my surprise, everyone loved it! —Elizabeth Martz, Pleasant Gap, Pennsylvania Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Corn Bread Chicken Bake
images.description: To make the most of leftover corn bread, try this hearty main dish casserole. It's moist, delicious and good on any occasion. —Madge Britton, Afton, Tennessee Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Golden Pork Chops
images.description: I have a large family and am always looking for easy recipes that will please all of them. This pork chop dish is definitely one of them. —Betty Sparks, Windsor, Connecticut Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Chili Tortilla Bake
images.description: A homestyle Tex-Mex casserole is all it takes to gather the whole family around the dinner table. With its popular flavors and bubbly cheese topping, there is never a need to worry about leftovers. —Celine Weldy, Cave Creek, Arizona Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Chicken Casserole
images.description: The original old family recipe for this casserole called for the sauce to be made from scratch. Through the years, I developed this version that takes less time to prepare and still tastes great. It's an attractive main dish. —Ruth Van Dyke, Traverse City, Michigan Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Black Beans with Bell Peppers & Rice
images.description: My meat and potatoes husband goes for this cheesy, hearty dinner, and the kids gobble it up. For extra kick, add a splash of hot sauce. —Stephanie Lambert, Moseley, Virgina Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Ham & Cheese Potato Casserole
images.description: This recipe makes two cheesy, delicious casseroles. Have one tonight and put the other on ice for a future busy weeknight. It's like having money in the bank when things get hectic! —Kari Adams, Fort Collins, Colorado Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Turkey & Spinach Stuffing Casserole
images.description: I know dried cranberries may seem like an odd ingredient to include in this dish, but they add just a hint of sweetness that makes this easy casserole so special. —Gilda Lester, Millsboro, Delaware Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: TLC (Thanksgiving Leftover Casserole)
images.description: Turkey, stuffing and veggies come together into a fabulous day-after casserole. Top it off with chopped pecans. There’s comfort in every bite.—Barbara Lento, Houston, Pennsylvania Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Church Supper Spaghetti
images.description: Because this recipe feeds so many, I often take it to church dinners and potlucks. This colorful dish also comes in handy when we have lots of help to feed on our farm.—Verlyn Wilson, Wilkinson, Indiana Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Chicken Zucchini Casserole
images.description: A co-worker shared this recipe that was originally her grandmother's. When I make it, I use a box of refrigerated cooked chicken and fresh zucchini my neighbor gives me from his garden. —Bev Dutro, Dayton, Ohio Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Mushroom Chicken with Wild Rice
images.description: Fix chicken dinner in a snap with this simple recipe. It warms you up, head to toe. —Cindy Cothern, Nampa, Idaho Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Creamy Ham & Cheese Casserole
images.description: I felt so proud when I created this recipe, which my husband loved! Leftover ham, convenient cooking creme and garlic-herb seasoning make this pasta toss so delicious. —Betsy Howard, Saint Louis, Missouri Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

items.title: 48 Delicious Ideas for Leftover Turkey
items.abstract: Time to try something clever and new with those Thanksgiving leftovers. We give big thanks for these delectable recipes that turn leftover turkey into irresistible potpies, casseroles, pizza and so much more.
items.author: Emily Tyra

images.title: Turkey Almond Salad
images.description: Our congregation was holding a luncheon at which I was helping, and we were supposed to use turkey left over from the church's Thanksgiving supper. I thought back to a salad I had tasted years before, then tried to come up with something similar. Everyone liked it so much that—at another church luncheon—we cooked a turkey for the specific purpose of making my salad. There was only one problem with this salad—as usual, I just created it as I was going along. When the other ladies asked me for the recipe. I had to scramble to put something on paper! At home, I make this whenever we have leftover turkey (it's also good with chicken). My husband and I have four grown daughters and seven grandchildren. We're grain and beef farmers. Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Thanksgiving Lover's Pizza
images.description: Got Thanksgiving Day leftovers? Forget ho-hum turkey sandwiches and try this unique take on pizza instead. Get creative with different variations: use whole berry or jelly cranberry sauce; add dollops of mashed potatoes on top; drizzle with turkey gravy; sprinkle with stuffing or dressing; or try unique pizza crust varieties. —Carla Parker, Anderson, South Carolina Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Turkey Cordon Bleu Casserole
images.description: Impress your holiday visitors with this fancier twist on the traditional casserole. —Kristine Blauert, Wabasha, Minnesota Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Turkey Quesadillas with Cranberry Salsa
images.description: A sweet-tart cranberry salsa is the ideal accompaniment to leftover turkey in this breezy quesadilla. With a hint of lemon and pear, the salsa is also good with chicken or pork. –Jodi Kristensen of Macomb, Michigan Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: TLC (Thanksgiving Leftover Casserole)
images.description: Turkey, stuffing and veggies come together into a fabulous day-after casserole. Top it off with chopped pecans. There’s comfort in every bite.—Barbara Lento, Houston, Pennsylvania Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Turkey Dumpling Soup
images.description: Simmering up a big pot of this soup is one of my favorite holiday traditions. This is a variation on a recipe my mom made while I was growing up. My husband and children can't get enough of the tender dumplings. Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Crunchy Almond Turkey Casserole
images.description: A special cousin shared the recipe for this comforting casserole. The almonds and water chestnuts give it a nice crunch. —Jill Black, Troy, Ontario Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Turkey Croquettes with Cranberry Salsa
images.description: This recipe is a great way to use up leftover turkey after the holidays.—Jacque Capurro, Anchorage, Alaska Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Derby Hot Browns
images.description: This classic open-faced sandwich created at the Brown Hotel in Louisville is easy to do with deli or leftover turkey, toast and a quick cheese sauce. —Taste of Home Test Kitchen Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Turkey & Corn Bread Stuffing Rellenos
images.description: Give your Thanksgiving leftovers a south of the border vibe with these zesty rellenos. They’re easy to make any time of year with roasted deli turkey and a box of corn stuffing. Adjust the heat by adding more or fewer peppers or adobo sauce. —Christine Friesenhahn, Boerne, Texas Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Stuffin' Muffins
images.description: If you love stuffing, you won’t be able to get enough of these fun muffin cups that not only make use of leftover stuffing but also green beans, turkey, mashed potatoes, cheddar and gravy. It’s a taste of Thanksgiving in every bite! —Pauline Porterfield, Roxboro, North Carolina Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Turkey Curry with Rice
images.description: When I have leftover turkey and a hankering for non-holiday food, I make turkey curry with carrots, cauliflower and mango chutney to spoon over rice. —Nancy Heishman, Las Vegas, Nevada Get Recipe
images.author: Provided by Taste of Home

images.title: Lemony Turkey Rice Soup
